Latest news in the region http://www.icsu.org hourly 1 2010-01-13T10:41:50Z ICSU Focal Points in LAC http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/icsu-focal-points-in-lac Panama University | March 9-10, 2015. Last March 9-10, ICSU ROLAC convoked the ICSU National Members\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Focal Points in Latin America and the Caribbean LAC for a workshop in the University of Panama in Panama City.

The event was inaugurated by Tom\ufffd\ufffds Diez - Research Director of the University of Panama, Arturo Mart\ufffd\ufffdnez \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Vice-Chair of the Regional Office for Latin America and the Caribbean, Manuel Limonta \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Director of ICSU ROLAC and Manuel de Le\ufffd\ufffdn \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Member of the Executive Board of ICSU.

The participants of the meeting consisted in 15 out of the 17 National Members in the region (Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Caribbean, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Guatemala, Jamaica, Panama, Peru, and Mexico), 2 countries in the process of becoming ICSU National Members (Ecuador and Honduras), 1 member of the ICSU Executive Board, 7 out of 9 members of the Regional Committee for Latin America and the Caribbean RCLAC, and the ICSU ROLAC Secretariat.

The Objectives of the workshop were: 1) to report the activities of ICSU ROLAC in the last 5 years, 2) to share experiences and successful cases along the region, 3) to promote actions to enhance the three pillars of ICSU in LAC, 4) to enhance the scientific links among all the organizations, 5) to allow ROLAC to have feedback from the Focal Points, and 6) to establish a communications network among the Focal Points.

The first day of the workshop was dedicated to a report of ROLAC\ufffd\ufffds general work in each priority area. During the second day, national cases - Brazil, Caribbean, Jamaica, Mexico, Cuba, Peru and Colombia- were presented, followed by a debate of possible LAC collaborations.

As a result, the Focal Points made a series of recommendations to ROLAC mainly oriented to 1) Focal Points and ROLAC collaboration, 2) the establishment of a regional scientific network, and 3) actions to increase of the visibility and impact of ICSU in the region.

The Secretariat of ROLAC took note of all the recommendations and suggestions for the strengthening of the Office and will take action as soon as possible.

The next meeting of ICSU Focal Points in LAC will be hosted by a National Member other than Panama a couple months before the 31st General Assembly of ICSU to be held in 2017.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-12-10T16:25:59Z News Item Science for Policy - Interoceanic Canal through Nicaragua http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/science-for-policy-interoceanic-canal-through-nicaragua International Workshop to Identify Major Scientific and Technical Issues Associated with the Interoceanic Canal through Nicaragua November 10th and 11th, 2014 The Academy of Sciences of Nicaragua invited the InterAmerican Network of Academies of Science (IANAS) and the International Council for Science \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Regional Office for Latin American and the Caribbean (ICSU-LAC) to co-sponsor an international workshop to explore scientific and technical issues associated with the proposed interoceanic canal through Nicaragua.

Participating in this workshop were 15 international scientists, as well as Nicaraguan researchers and scientists. Selected by IANAS, these scientists are world experts in the pertinent disciplines, including: biodiversity, conservation, marine biology, limnology and lacustrine ecosystems, civil and environmental engineering, hydrology and hydraulics, public policy, water resource management, water quality, economics, national and international security, and risk assessment.

The main objective of the workshop was to identify and discuss technical and scientific questions pertaining to the Interoceanic Canal Project and sub-projects, to contribute to a public, transparent and well-informed debate.

The Summary of Discussions is available here.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-12-02T17:50:00Z News Item Future Earth 2025 Vision http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/future-earth-2025-vision Future Earth has published the Future Earth 2025 Vision, outlining what Future Earth will contribute over the coming decade to achieve its vision for people to thrive in a sustainable and equitable world. The Future Earth 2025 Vision sets out an ambitious, holistic framework for research and capacity mobilisation. Central to achieving the vision is a commitment to co-design and co-produce knowledge in collaboration with societal partners in order to develop solutions-oriented research that responds to the sustainability challenges facing society.

The Future Earth 2025 Vision is available in English for download in Future Earth webpage.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-11-12T19:41:35Z News Item ICSU grants programme open for applications http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/icsu-grants-programme-open-for-applications Members are now invited to submit applications for the 2015 ICSU grants programme. Since 2008, the programme has offered up to ten awards of 30 000 euros. Following a review conducted by the ICSU Committee on Scientific Planning and Review (CSPR), the programme has been developed to place a particular focus on innovative, multidisciplinary activities. In addition, proposals will now need to be led by an ICSU Scientific Union, with encouragement to involve other organisations in the ICSU family (Scientific Unions, Interdisciplinary Bodies, Joint Initiatives, ICSU Regional Offices, National Scientific Members, or International or National Scientific Associates) as Formal Supporting Applicants.

The application process for 2015 grants is now open.\ufffd\ufffd All applications which wish to receive the Formal Support of the Regional Office for Latin America and the Caribbean must be submitted by email to angelica.bucio@icsu-latin-america-caribbean.org no later than 2 November 2014.

In order to have ROLAC's support, the proposal has to 1) be linked to at least one of the priority areas (Biodiversity, Disaster Risk Reduction, Sustainable Energy and Mathematics Education) and/or 2) at least one ICSU Pillar (Scientific research collaboration, Science for Policy and Universality of Science). 3) The involvement of women, indigenous people and/or early career scientists is a plus. The more of these characteristics, the better. Finally, any proposal supported by ROLAC 4) must be linked to the Latin America and the Caribbean region.

If you have a project and would like some assessment or help finding partners, please contact Angelica Bucio and the Regional Office will be glad to help.

The necessary documents are available for ICSU members\ufffd\ufffdin the Member Zone or can be asked to Angelica Bucio.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-09-11T16:34:11Z News Item Society&Nature http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/society-nature Dialogue between natural and social scientists on the challenges of sustainability Organized by ICSU ROLAC and ISSC Venue: Brazilian Academy of Sciences, Rio de Janeiro September 30th \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd October 1st, 2014 Future Earth is a new 10-year international research initiative that will develop the knowledge for responding effectively to the risks and opportunities of global environmental change and for supporting transformation towards global sustainability in the coming decades. This flagship ICSU program aims to mobilize the scientific community and strengthen communication links between scientists and policy makers. The program is based on effective interdisciplinary collaboration across the natural and social sciences, humanities, economics and technology development, to find the best scientific solutions to these problems that require multifaceted approaches. The disciplinary structure of our traditional education and research programs however do not favor the development of multi and trans- disciplinary research to solve problems that involve the community.

In March 2014 The International Social Science Council (ISSC) launched a new global research funding programme on \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdTransformations to sustainability\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd intended\ufffd\ufffdas a major contribution to the work of Future Earth of\ufffd\ufffdpromote research on the fundamental and innovative processes of social transformations needed to secure effective, equitable and durable solutions to some of the most urgent problems of global change and sustainability \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd including climate change, biodiversity loss, water and food security, energy consumption, and poverty and growing inequalities.

The main objective of this workshop is to facilitate communication between natural and social scientists around energy issues, socio- environmental risks, urban mobility, and problems of poverty and growing inequality. ICSU ROLAC and ISSC expect to identify specific procedures and methodologies to facilitate the development of trans disciplinary projects within the research framework of Future Earth and encourage the creation of multidisciplinary research teams interested on performing this type of research. Successful experiences of joint natural and social science research oriented to solve a specific problem will be presented

Objectives:

(1) To facilitate communication between natural and social scientists around energy sustainability, socio-environmental risks, urban mobility, and problems of poverty and growing inequality.

(2) To identify specific research areas for multidisciplinary work, as well as procedures and methodologies that could facilitate the development of trans- disciplinary research projects within the framework of Future Earth.

(3) To promote the creation of multi and trans disciplinary research teams interested on performing this type of solution oriented research in sustainability issues and the risks inherent to climate change.

Expected outcomes

(1) Guidelines for the joint action of natural and social science research on issues of sustainability and climate change.

(2) Identification of specific research areas for joint social and natural sciences research work in the region within the framework of Future Earth.

(3) Set of procedures and methodologies oriented to facilitate the creation of joint social and natural scientist teams for the development of trans- disciplinary research projects within the framework of Future Earth.

(4) Recommendations for a fundraising strategy for multi and trans disciplinary projects in energy sustainability, socio-environmental risks, urban health and mobility, and problems of poverty and growing inequality.

\ufffd\ufffd

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-09-08T17:15:00Z News Item 2nd IRDR Conference http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/2nd-irdr-conference The IRDR Programme, in partnership with the China Association for Science and Technology (CAST), hosted the 2nd IRDR Conference, under the theme \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIntegrated Disaster Risk Science: A Tool for Sustainability,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd from 7 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 9 June 2014 at the Beijing International Convention Center (BICC) in Beijing, China. The Conference emphasized the importance of science as a tool to address hazard risks and issues of sustainable development.

The conference featured a series of plenaries and break-out sessions dealing with the challenges of implementing integrated disaster risk research, inter-organisational collaboration, and policy, as well as the interaction with sustainable development activities. The sessions addressed the range of environmental hazards, vulnerability, and sustainability globally and regionally.

IRDR Conference 2014 brought together leading experts in the field of disaster risk reduction from all academic and professional specialities to help create a global IRDR community and bring continued worldwide attention to the IRDR programme.

-Andrea Sealy Ph.D.*

Caribbean Institute for Meteorology and Hydrology, Barbados

\ufffd\ufffd

*Andrea Sealy participated on this meeting supported by ICSU ROLAC.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-07-28T15:50:04Z News Item International Seminar on forensic investigations on desasters FORIN 2014 http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/international-seminar-on-forensic-investigations-on-desasters-forin-2014 Forin is an innovative methodology that focuses on the root causes of disasters, as well as the risks The International Seminar on Forensic Disaster Investigations was organized by the Integrated Research on Disaster Risk (IRDR); the International Consortium of Landslides (ICL); International Geographical Union (IGU); Mexican Academy of Sciences (AMC); National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM) and ICSU ROLAC. Was held on 24 and 25 February 2014 in Mexico City at the Institute of Geography, UNAM.

The objectives of this event were to examine the FORIN methodology and apply it to various research activities, management or decision-making in the context of Disaster Reduction and the Comprehensive Disaster Risk Management in different countries of Latin America.

The seminar was divided into two parts. The first featured presentations by researchers with extensive experience in the subject. Among them are Anthony Oliver-Smith, Ian Burton and Gustavo Wilches-Chaux.

The second part was developed in participatory workshops where all young people from several countries of the region were able to exchange ideas and experiences. These workshops were in turn to the description of specific cases that facilitated the discussion.

\ufffd\ufffd

The products of this seminar were:

1) The ability to gather in Mexico to some of the most important scientific topic of forensic investigations worldwide

2) The significant participation of young scientists from different countries in Latin America and the Caribbean

3) The establishment of connections with important scientist of this field with young scientist of our Region for further cooperation in this area.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-06-25T17:16:19Z News Item 11th TAEMUN http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/11th-taemun Manuel Limonta inaugurated the United Nations Model of one of the most important schools in Mexico City. On 6 February, Manuel Limonta was invited to inaugurate the 11th United Nations Model organized by Tomas Alva Edison School, one of the most important schools in Mexico City. Twenty one Mexican schools from basic education to college level participated in these Spanish, English and French simulations. There were approximately 500 assistants among students (280), parents and teachers. This event allowed ROLAC to strengthen links with the Mexican education environment creating new links, especially in the Mathematics Education priority area; and to be better known in the region.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-06-10T21:29:03Z News Item 4th International Conference General Young Academy http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/4th-international-conference-general-young-academy The International Conference and General Meeting is the annual key event of GYA and its main meeting in which the members can work together on the goals of this global organization. As the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdvoice of young scientists around the world,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd the Global Young Academy (GYA) aims to empower and mobilize young scientists to address issues of particular importance to early career scientists. The 200 members, leading young scientists from 58 countries and all continents, are currently working in groups focused on improving Early Scientific Careers, Women in Science and Technology, Science-Society Dialogue, Science-Education, and Interdisciplinary Research.

The International Conference and General Meeting is the annual key event of GYA and its main meeting in which the members can work together on the goals of this global organization. This year, it took place at the Faculty of Physical and Mathematical Sciences of the Universidad de Chile and Pontifica Universidad Cat\ufffd\ufffdlica de Chile in Santiago de Chile, Chile, from 21 to 25 May 2014. The theme of this year\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Conference was \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdNatural Resources in a Finite World\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd.

The participants included 80 young scientists GYA members, Chilean young scientists and some other guests among which was ICSU. Some of the distinguished guests were Sergio Lavandero -Vice President of Research and Development, Universidad de Chile-; Juan Asenjo -President of the Chilean Academy of Science, Co-Chair of the InterAmerican Network of Academies of Sciences (IANAS), IAP representative-; Mar\ufffd\ufffda Elena Boisier -acting President of the National Commission for Scientific and Technological Research (CONICYT), Government of Chile; Jorge Sequeira- Director, UNESCO Office of Education for Latin America and the Caribbean, Chile-, and Howard Alper -Chair, Government of Canada\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Science, Technology and Innovation Council-.

ICSU ROLAC Communications Officer, Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Bucio, participated in this Assembly in representation of the International Council for Science. She was part of the panel \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdDiscussion on Natural Resources in a Finite World\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd together with Jorge Sequeira, Howard Alper and GYA members: Antonio Andreoni, Olanike Adeyemo, and James Tickner. Also, she gave the Keynote \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdICSU & Future Earth: knowledge and support to accelerate our transformations to a sustainable world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd where were presented the basics of ICSU and the advances of Future Earth. In both interventions, there were offered several opportunities of collaboration among ICSU, Future Earth and GYA.

In short, the main outcomes of the meeting were: 1) the establishment of a very important networking, 2) the several possibilities for future collaborations and 3) the acknowledgment of young scientists (especially the ones from the LAC region) on Future Earth, ICSU and ICSU ROLAC.

Click here and here for pictures.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-06-10T21:25:00Z News Item EURIAS FELLOWSHIP PROGRAMME 2015-2016 http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/eurias-fellowship-programme-2015-2016 The European Institutes for Advanced Study (EURIAS) Fellowship Programme is an international researcher mobility programme offering 10-month residencies in one of the 16 participating Institutes. EURIAS Fellowships are mainly offered in the fields of the humanities and social sciences but may also be granted to scholars in life and exact sciences, provided that their proposed research project does not require laboratory facilities and that it interfaces with humanities and social sciences.

For the 2015-2016 academic year, EURIAS offers 44 fellowships (22 junior and 22 senior positions).

All IAS have agreed on common standards, including the provision of a living allowance (in the\ufffd\ufffdrange of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 26,000 for a junior fellow and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 38,000 for a senior fellow), accommodation (or a\ufffd\ufffdmobility allowance), a research budget, plus coverage of travel expenses.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-04-30T17:45:00Z News Item Call: Identification of existing advances and linkages of the scientific and academic community initiatives with Disaster Risk Reduction in LAC http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/open-call-identification-of-existing-advances-and-linkages-of-the-scientific-and-academic-community-initiatives-with-disaster-risk-reduction-in-lac The Steering Committee on Risk Prevention and Management of ICSU-LAC made a call for a consultancy: Identification of existing advances and linkages of the scientific and academic community initiatives with Disaster Risk Reduction in Latin America and the Caribbean. The call closed on March 23, 2014.

In 2012, recognizing\ufffd\ufffd that disaster risk reduction is a critical dimension of the global poverty reduction agenda, and an integral part of development efforts, ICSU led the conformation of the Steering Committee on Risk Prevention and Management of ICSU-LAC. The purpose of the Committee is to give advice that contributes to strengthening the linkages of the scientific community and its knowledge with the current activities led by national institutions to reduce the impact of disasters in the Americas region. The advice can be provided in the design of a strategy oriented to fill existing gaps and facilitate the coordination of the scientific communities, efforts and knowledge for building resilience of nations as per their commitment to the Hyogo Framework for Action.

In order to provide advice on the areas that should be strengthened for the integration of the agendas of the scientific community and disaster risk reduction practitioners, the Steering Committee needs to have an assessment of current advancements, existing mechanisms and, projects, their scope and their funding situation (amount, provider agency, sustainability, etc.). The assessment will provide information, which will inform development of\ufffd\ufffda\ufffd\ufffdstrategy\ufffd\ufffdfor integrating and reinforcing current efforts within the region.

  • Period of the consultancy : 3 months
  • Funding for the consultancy: The consultancy is a fixed sum for US$ 15,000.00
  • Requirements: The expert (she or he) should have a minimum a Master Degree preferably a PhD. Her or his university background\ufffd\ufffdmay be: geology, geography, civil engineering, socio-economy or any other\ufffd\ufffduniversity degree\ufffd\ufffdrelated to disaster risk reduction. She or He should have from 7 to 10 years of experience in developing, coordinating, and evaluating projects. Experience in management of scientific projects related to disaster risk reduction will be an advantage.
  • Language: Excellent Spanish speaking and writing skills; advanced knowledge of English is an asset.
  • How to apply:Qualified candidates should send the following documentation per email to icsu.rolac@gmail.com, and angelica.bucio@icsu-latin-american-caribbean.org
  1. Motivation letter
  2. Economic proposal
  3. Technical proposal (two pages)
  4. CV

When sending the documents, include your complete name and the vacancy number for this consultancy in the subject (Reference ICSU /DR/13.02.2014).

Please note that applications received after the deadline will not be accepted. Applicants will be contacted only if they are under serious consideration.

Deadline: March 23, 2014.

Please click here to download the full Call.

\ufffd\ufffd

The Steering Committee thanks all the applicants for submitting their proposals and informs that PhD. Virginia Jim\ufffd\ufffdnez was elected by majority.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-02-13T17:35:00Z News Item Applications: International Seminar on FORIN http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/applications-international-seminar-on-forin From 24-25 February 2014, the Institute of Geography of the National Autonomous University of Mexico in Mexico City, Mexico, will host an international seminar on Forensic Investigations of Disasters (FORIN). This seminar on Forensic Investigations of Disasters (FORIN) is the follow-up to the International Workshop on FORIN Associated with Landslides, which was held from 24 June to 5 July 2013. Click here for the report on this workshop [PDF 1.03MB].

The international seminar on FORIN is directed at young Latin American scientists and students from all disciplines related to the field of disaster risk reduction (DRR), where they will learn more about FORIN, a methodology proposed by the IRDR Programme in order to understand the complex and underlying causes of disasters.

Please visit this link to know all the details.

]]> No publisher Ang\ufffd\ufffdlica Sof\ufffd\ufffda Bucio M\ufffd\ufffdndez 2014-02-06T23:53:11Z News Item Jeffrey Sachs Launches Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) on Sustainable Development http://www.icsu.org/icsu-latin-america/news-centre/news/jeffrey-sachs-launches-massive-open-online-course-mooc-on-sustainable-development Get to know the free, global online course \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Age of Sustainable Development\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. On January 21, 2014, Professor Jeffrey Sachs, under the auspices of the SDSN, launched the free, global online course \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe Age of Sustainable Development\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd. The 14-week, university-level course is available through Coursera and open to anyone interested in the field of sustainable development, including students and development professionals working in government, corporations, and non-profit organizations. The course is offered for credit by some several universities who are members of the SDSN. These universities offer local co-teaching. During the course of 2014, the SDSN will launch additional online courses in collaboration with SDSN members.
